title: Who is the most overrated rapper? - Quora

response.answer_text: Jay-Z  This one may piss off a lot of hip-hop heads, but so be it. Recently, a lot of rappers and celebrity rap fans have been releasing their top 50 rapper lists. And do you know what a lot of them have in common? Look at all these lists and tell me. Zoom in if you have to.  This one’s by radio personality Ebro Darden[1]  This list is by RapGenius CCO Brendan Frederick. [2]  And this list was compiled by rapper Troy Ave. [3] You know what all three of these lists have in common? I can think of two things. All three lists are made by respected and influential figures in the hip-hop game.All three lists feature Jay-Z at either first or second. The only time he’s not ranked first is when he loses out to Tupac, technically making him widely considered to be the best rapper alive.It all reminds me of this one line Jay-Z (referred to here as Hov) said on a song with Kanye West. Hov’s a living legend and I’ll tell you why Everybody wanna be Hov and Hov’s still alive[4] And what I’m wondering here is why Jay-Z’s reached GOAT status in the minds of most hip-hop heads. What has he done to earn the title of ‘Best Rapper Alive’, especially while Nas, Rakim, Royce da 5′9″ and Andre 3000 still continue to walk this earth? I’m sorry, but I say Jay-Z isn’t fit to hold Nas’s cock as far as rappers go. Nas is hardly the only rapper I consider to be more deserving of the GOAT title than Jay-Z, but let’s stack him up against Jay-Z in several of the categories that form the criteria for Best Rapper. [5]  Storytelling This category goes to Nas by a long shot. In fact, Nas is such a good storyteller that XXL Magazine literally wrote an article of *20 *of Nas’ best feats of storytelling in rap. The following quote is taken directly from that article Esco (Nas) has acquired the glow, collected all the Infinity Stones and lived in a Super Saiyan state of being for more than two decades. The Queens legend’s innate ability to whimsically string words together is punctuated by his penchant for delivering some of the most vividly picturesque tracks in rap history.[6] We’re talking about the man who dropped the greatest solo album in rap history. The emcee who has masterpiece narratives like One Love, I Gave You Power, I Can, 2nd Childhood and Sekou Story under his belt. What does Jay-Z have that can compare to that? 99 Problems? Momma Loves Me? Meet The Parents? Nah. Not only is he outclassed here by Nas, but also Slick Rick, Scarface, Warren G and even Biz Markie. Flow This is possibly Jay-Z’s weakest area, and it shows, especially in comparison to Nas. Here’s a rhyme scheme analysis from NY State of Mind, widely considered to be one of Nas’s best songs.  Meanwhile, here’s a similar analysis of Jay-Z’s first verse on Renegade, also considered to be one of his very best.  If the visualisation of this flow doesn’t illustrate it for you, I don’t know what to tell you. There’s this beautiful symmetry in rhyme schemes that’s required for a rapper to have good flow, and Jay-Z oftentimes doesn’t have it. His cadences are very often simplistic. Nothing on Nas, Big L, Eminem or even Crooked I. Rap Beefs This is one category I can directly put Jay-Z and Nas head-to-head in. Throughout the early 2000s, the two rappers were locked in a giant feud that, while personal and ugly, gave us two incredible diss tracks, entitled Takeover and Ether respectively. Who had the better diss track, you ask? Well, people commonly use the slang term ‘ethered’ in daily life to describe someone who’s been obliterated and fucked up beyond recognition in some form of competition.  As great as Takeover may have been, it wasn’t the best. Nas won that beef by a long shot. And if you can’t win a rap beef, how can you be considered the best? Sales and Longevity Here’s a category where I will admit Jay-Z reigns supreme. Hova’s one of the bestselling artists of the 21st century. Any single he releases cracks the Hot 100. He’s almost guaranteed platinum if he releases an album. Nas doesn’t have that kind of commercial success. And longevity? Yes, he wins there. Though his albums may not be the definitive best, (projects like Enter the 36, Illmatic and Midnight Marauders win there) they certainly stand the test of time much better than, say, LL Cool J. And as far as longevity? He’s been in the game since 1995, and he’s been consistently relevant and famous during this time. But the likes of MC Hammer and Vanilla Ice prove that sales aren’t everything in hip-hop. Nor is longevity. Biggie was only active for five years, Pac was only active for six and Big L for seven. It’s not about how long you last, it’s about what you make of it. Impact On The Culture Yet again, Jay-Z is the absolute undisputed king here. He’s completely revolutionised the game in a way that’s never been seen before, and I’m far from the only person to think that. [7] He gave the world Kanye West, became hip-hop’s first billionaire, fought for artists’ rights to their own intellectual property, influenced countless rappers in the game and just generally built a dynasty that’ll never be forgotten. But so many of these achievements simply weren’t made when Jay-Z was on the mic. Yeah, yeah, he was influential. But you know who else has been influential in the hip-hop game? Rick Rubin. Dr Dre. Puffy. And yet you’ll never see them on any reputable Top Rappers list. In my opinion, being the best rapper isn’t about what you do when you’re not rapping, no matter how influential it is. Nah, being the best rapper is simply about one thing: rapping the best.  Look, there’s no doubt that Jay-Z has been revolutionary to not only hip-hop, but even the world. Nor am I disputing that he’s an incredibly talented rapper, and that he’s cemented his spot in hip-hop’s top 20 or 25 of all time. I just feel as though his skills as a lyricist are often overrated simply because of the impact he’s had on the game. Jay-Z’s a great rapper, I was never disputing that. He’s just not the best. Footnotes[1] Ebro Darden on Instagram: “#TheRealTop50 .... My handwritten list. 🤔 (*) means could be higher ...”[2] bfred 👍🏻 on Twitter[3] GOD is Great Paper $traight on Instagram: “WHO SHOULD BE ON & WHO SHOULD BE OFF❓ Read: List is NOT Particular Order after #4 .... (Criteria Based On Having at least 1 out of 5 )  1.…”[4] Hov's a living legend and I'll tell you why / Everybody wanna be Hov and Hov's still alive[5] Best Rapper Alive: What Makes A Great Rapper?[6] 20 of Nas' Most Unforgettable Storytelling Songs - XXL[7] In Defense of Jay-Z as the Most Important Person in Hip-Hop History

Juice Wrld.  Now, hey, before you get all tiger on me, (especially you Zack), just listen. The thing that aggravates me the most is not Juice himself but his fans. Most of his fans only discovered him after he died. And, now all of the sudden, he has all these fans. Just because he died? I do like his music. But I’m not the type to go listen to someone just because they get fame after they’re dead. The overrated aspect mostly comes from the fans that just listen to him because they think it’s cool and because they heard he died so now they go listen to him. Here are his stats on spotify:  As you can see, Lucid Dreams is an extremely overrated song. I’m sure you’ve seen it on those fake depressed 13 year old snapchat stories with the caption, “I will never love again.” Boy, you’re literally 13, the only thing you’ve ever loved is your momma.  It annoys me. Rip. xoxo,abi good
